required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Diagnosis of Acute Appendicitis: Low-dose Computed Tomography (CT) Versus Standard-dose CT
clinical_study.official_title: Negative Appendectomy Rate Following Low-dose CT vs. Standard-dose CT

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether low-dose CT is not inferior to standard-dose CT in the rate of unnecessary appendectomy.

detailed_description.textblock:
Acute appendicitis is a very common disease with the lifetime incidence of 7%. Abdomen CT is an established first-line diagnostic test in patients suspected of having acute appendicitis. Since many individuals suspected of having acute appendicitis are young, with a mean age of 30 years, CT radiation is of particular concern.
The estimated lifetime attributable risk of death from cancer due to the radiation exposure of a single abdomen CT study is 2-7/10,000 for average adults ranging 20-40 years in age.
The purpose of this study is to determine whether low-dose CT is not inferior to standard-dose CT in the negative appendectomy rate.

primary_outcome.description: Number of participants with unnecessary appendectomies (removal of un-inflamed appendix)

secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants who need additional imaging test(s) to diagnose or rule out appendicitis
Number of participants with appendiceal perforation
Time interval between the CT acquisition and non-incidental appendectomy

secondary_outcome.measure: Interval Between CT and Discharge Without Surgery
secondary_outcome.description: Time interval between the CT acquisition and discharge without surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Interval From CT to Discharge After Appendectomy
secondary_outcome.description: Time interval between the CT acquisition and discharge after appendectomy

secondary_outcome.measure: Likelihood of Appendicitis in CT Report in Patients Confirmed as Having Appendicitis
secondary_outcome.description: Grade 1. Definitely absent. Clinical observation is recommended. Grade 2. Probably absent. Clinical observation is recommended. Grade 3. Indeterminate. Clinical observation or surgical exploration is recommended. Grade 4. Probably present. Surgical exploration is recommended. Grade 5. Definitely present. Surgical exploration is recommended. The data is used to calculate sensitivity, specificity, area under receiver-operating-curve and to measure diagnostic confidence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Likelihood of Appendicitis in CT Report in Patients Confirmed as Not Having Appendicitis
secondary_outcome.description: Grade 1. Definitely absent. Clinical observation is recommended. Grade 2. Probably absent. Clinical observation is recommended. Grade 3. Indeterminate. Clinical observation or surgical exploration is recommended. Grade 4. Probably present. Surgical exploration is recommended. Grade 5. Definitely present. Surgical exploration is recommended. The data are used to calculate sensitivity, specificity, area under receiver-operating-curve and to measure diagnostic confidence.

secondary_outcome.measure: Diagnosis of Appendiceal Perforation in CT in Patients With Confirmed Appendicitis.
secondary_outcome.description: True positive: Perforation was rated as present in CT report and confirmed as present. False positive: Perforation was rated as present in CT report and confirmed as absent. True negative: Perforation was rated as absent in CT report and confirmed as absent. False negative: Perforation was rated as absent in CT report and confirmed as present. The data are used to calculate sensitivity and specificity.
Grade 0. Not identified Grade 1. Unsure or partly visualized Grade 2. Clearly and entirely visualized

intervention.description: 2 mSv in an average patient (Low-dose (1/4 to 1/5 of standard-dose))
8 mSv in an average patient (Standard-dose CT)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Suspected of having acute appendicitis
- Referred for abdomen CT from Emergency Department
Exclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index < 18.5 kg/m2 (ultrasonography is favored)
- Intravenous contrast-enhancement is contraindicated

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Dates of the recruitment period: September 2009 to January 2011 Types of location: an emergency department in an urban tertiary hospital in Korea
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: None of the enrolled participants were excluded from the trial before assignment to group.

outcome.title: Likelihood of Appendicitis in CT Report in Patients Confirmed as Having Appendicitis
outcome.description: Grade 1. Definitely absent. Clinical observation is recommended. Grade 2. Probably absent. Clinical observation is recommended. Grade 3. Indeterminate. Clinical observation or surgical exploration is recommended. Grade 4. Probably present. Surgical exploration is recommended. Grade 5. Definitely present. Surgical exploration is recommended. The data is used to calculate sensitivity, specificity, area under receiver-operating-curve and to measure diagnostic confidence.
outcome.population: Participants confirmed to have appendicitis. Intention to treat. Complete case analysis. There can be missing data if CT report was not made following predefined structured format.

outcome.title: Radiation Dose
outcome.description: Radiation dose is measured in terms of dose-length product (mGy•cm) as displayed in the CT console. The "length" indicates the scan range.
outcome.population: All participants who underwent CT. Intention to treat. Complete case analysis.

group.title: Low-dose CT
group.description: Aimed to 2 mSv in an average patient

measure.title: Radiation Dose
measure.description: Radiation dose is measured in terms of dose-length product (mGy•cm) as displayed in the CT console. The "length" indicates the scan range.
measure.population: All participants who underwent CT. Intention to treat. Complete case analysis.

outcome.title: Estimate of Carcinogenic Risk Induced by CT Radiation
outcome.description: Age- and sex-specific carcinogenic risk induced by CT radiation. This is not an actual measurement but an estimate of the stochastic risk, based on assumption and calculation from radiation dose used.

outcome.title: Diagnosis of Appendiceal Perforation in CT in Patients With Confirmed Appendicitis.
outcome.description: True positive: Perforation was rated as present in CT report and confirmed as present. False positive: Perforation was rated as present in CT report and confirmed as absent. True negative: Perforation was rated as absent in CT report and confirmed as absent. False negative: Perforation was rated as absent in CT report and confirmed as present. The data are used to calculate sensitivity and specificity.
outcome.population: Participants confirmed to have appendicitis. Intention to treat. Complete case analysis. There can be missing data if CT report was not made following predefined structured format.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: In this diagnostic trial, participants have a variety of abdominal diseases. Events with CTCAE v4 Grade 2 or less are not considered reportable according to the Study Protocol.
